name: Paracetamol (acetaminophen)
description_and_medical_use: Analgesic and antipyretic used to relieve pain (headache, toothache, muscle pain) and reduce fever.
common_side_effects: Rare allergic reactions; liver damage with overdose or chronic excessive use.
recommended_dosage: Adults: 500 mg–1 g every 4–6 hours as needed; maximum commonly 3–4 g (3000–4000 mg) per 24 hours depending on guidance and product.
tips_for_safe_use: Do not take with other products containing paracetamol. Reduce dose or avoid if severe liver disease or heavy alcohol use. Read product leaflet.

name: Ibuprofen
description_and_medical_use: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for pain, inflammation and fever (e.g. muscle pain, menstrual pain).
common_side_effects: Stomach upset, heartburn, headache, dizziness; increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and fluid retention; can raise blood pressure.
recommended_dosage: Adults: 200–400 mg every 4–6 hours as needed; maximum commonly 1,200–2,400 mg/day depending on product and supervision.
tips_for_safe_use: Take with food to reduce stomach upset. Avoid if history of peptic ulcer, uncontrolled high blood pressure, or advanced heart failure unless advised by a doctor.

name: Amoxicillin
description_and_medical_use: A commonly used penicillin antibiotic for many bacterial infections (ear, throat, chest, urinary, skin).
common_side_effects: Nausea, diarrhea, rash; rare allergic (anaphylactic) reactions in penicillin-allergic patients.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult dose: 250–500 mg every 8 hours or 500–875 mg every 12 hours (depending on infection and local guidance).
tips_for_safe_use: Complete the full prescribed course even if you feel better. Tell the prescriber of any penicillin allergy. Avoid unnecessary use to limit resistance.

name: Amoxicillin-clavulanate (co-amoxiclav)
description_and_medical_use: Broad-spectrum antibiotic (amoxicillin combined with a beta-lactamase inhibitor) for bacterial infections resistant to amoxicillin alone.
common_side_effects: Diarrhea, nausea, rash, rarely liver enzyme changes.
recommended_dosage: Depends on formulation; common adult regimens include 500/125 mg every 8 hours or 875/125 mg every 12 hours.
tips_for_safe_use: Take with food to reduce stomach upset; use only when prescribed; report persistent diarrhea.

name: Ciprofloxacin
description_and_medical_use: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used for certain serious bacterial infections (e.g., complicated urinary tract infections, some GI infections).
common_side_effects: Nausea, dizziness, tendon pain (rare but serious), possible photosensitivity, CNS effects.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult doses vary by infection: often 250–750 mg every 12 hours; follow prescriber instructions.
tips_for_safe_use: Avoid unnecessary use; report tendon pain or unusual muscle weakness immediately; may interact with some minerals (separate antacids/calcium/iron).

name: Metronidazole
description_and_medical_use: Antibiotic/antiprotozoal used for anaerobic bacterial infections and protozoal infections (e.g., bacterial vaginosis, giardiasis) and some dental infections.
common_side_effects: Nausea, metallic taste, headache; rarely neurological effects with long use.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult regimens vary; for many infections 400–500 mg every 8–12 hours for a specified course.
tips_for_safe_use: Avoid alcohol during treatment and for 48 hours after finishing (can cause flushing/ nausea). Complete full course.

name: Azithromycin
description_and_medical_use: Macrolide antibiotic used for respiratory infections, some sexually transmitted infections, and other bacterial infections.
common_side_effects: Diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain; rarely heart rhythm changes (QT prolongation).
recommended_dosage: Common adult course: 500 mg on day 1 then 250 mg once daily on days 2–5 (regimens vary by indication).
tips_for_safe_use: Tell prescriber about any heart problems or medicines that affect heart rhythm. Use only as prescribed.

name: Metformin
description_and_medical_use: First-line oral medication for type 2 diabetes to lower blood glucose by reducing hepatic glucose production and improving insulin sensitivity.
common_side_effects: Gastrointestinal upset (nausea, diarrhea) is common; rare risk of lactic acidosis in severe kidney impairment.
recommended_dosage: Typical starting dose 500 mg once or twice daily with meals; usual maintenance 500–2000 mg/day (often up to 2,000 mg daily); follow prescriber.
tips_for_safe_use: Take with food to reduce GI effects. Check kidney function before starting and periodically. Stop temporarily if vomiting/diarrhea or before iodinated contrast unless advised.

name: Glibenclamide (glyburide)
description_and_medical_use: A sulfonylurea oral antidiabetic agent that increases insulin release from the pancreas; used in type 2 diabetes.
common_side_effects: Hypoglycaemia (low blood sugar), weight gain, nausea.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult doses vary (e.g., 2.5–5 mg once daily, adjusted to effect); follow prescriber and local formularies.
tips_for_safe_use: Monitor blood glucose regularly. Be aware of signs of hypoglycaemia and carry a fast-acting sugar source. Use with caution in elderly and those with renal impairment.

name: Enalapril
description_and_medical_use: ACE inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure.
common_side_effects: Dizziness (especially on first dose), dry cough, elevated potassium, rare angioedema.
recommended_dosage: Typical starting dose 2.5–5 mg once daily; maintenance commonly 5–20 mg daily depending on condition.
tips_for_safe_use: Monitor blood pressure and kidney function, and potassium. Avoid during pregnancy.

name: Atenolol
description_and_medical_use: Beta-blocker for hypertension, angina and heart rate control.
common_side_effects: Tiredness, cold extremities, slow heart rate; may worsen asthma/COPD symptoms in some.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult dose 25–100 mg once daily depending on indication.
tips_for_safe_use: Do not stop suddenly; discuss with prescriber if you have breathing problems or diabetes (can mask hypoglycaemia).

name: Furosemide
description_and_medical_use: Loop diuretic used to treat edema (fluid overload) and some cases of hypertension.
common_side_effects: Increased urination, electrolyte disturbances (low potassium, low magnesium), dizziness, dehydration.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult oral dose 20–80 mg once daily (may be higher for some conditions); dosing individualized.
tips_for_safe_use: Monitor electrolytes and kidney function. Be cautious about dehydration and orthostatic dizziness; take in morning if possible.

name: Omeprazole
description_and_medical_use: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) used for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GERD), peptic ulcers, and to prevent NSAID-related ulcers.
common_side_effects: Headache, abdominal pain, nausea; long-term use associated with increased risk of fractures, B12 deficiency, and infections (e.g., C. difficile) in some.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult dose 20 mg once daily for many indications; higher doses for some conditions.
tips_for_safe_use: Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest necessary time. Discuss long-term use risks with clinician.

name: Pantoprazole
description_and_medical_use: Proton pump inhibitor similar to omeprazole used for acid-related stomach problems (GERD, ulcers).
common_side_effects: Headache, abdominal pain, diarrhea; long-term risks similar to other PPIs.
recommended_dosage: Common adult dose 20–40 mg once daily depending on indication.
tips_for_safe_use: Follow same precautions as for other PPIs; check with doctor about long-term use.

name: Salbutamol (albuterol) inhaler
description_and_medical_use: Short-acting bronchodilator used to relieve acute asthma symptoms and wheeze (rescue inhaler).
common_side_effects: Tremor, increased heart rate, nervousness, throat irritation.
recommended_dosage: Normal rescue dose: 1–2 puffs when needed; can be repeated (commonly up to 4 times in 24 hours for routine use; acute attacks may require different guidance).
tips_for_safe_use: Learn correct inhaler technique (use a spacer if available for children). Seek urgent care for severe breathlessness. Keep inhaler accessible.

name: Gentamicin (injectable)
description_and_medical_use: Aminoglycoside antibiotic for serious Gram-negative infections, often used in hospitals (injectable).
common_side_effects: Kidney toxicity, hearing (vestibular/cochlear) toxicity; careful monitoring required.
recommended_dosage: Dose varies by weight, renal function and indication (usually given by injection); use only under hospital / prescriber guidance.
tips_for_safe_use: Requires monitoring of kidney function and sometimes drug levels. Not for routine outpatient use without supervision.

name: Atorvastatin
description_and_medical_use: Statin used to lower cholesterol and reduce cardiovascular risk.
common_side_effects: Muscle aches, elevated liver enzymes (rare serious muscle injury), GI upset.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult starting dose 10–20 mg once daily; maintenance 10–80 mg once daily depending on target and risk.
tips_for_safe_use: Have baseline and periodic liver tests as advised. Report unexplained muscle pain or weakness.

name: Doxycycline
description_and_medical_use: Tetracycline antibiotic used for respiratory infections, some skin infections, malaria prophylaxis, and other indications.
common_side_effects: Photosensitivity (sunburn easier), GI upset, tooth discoloration in children if used during tooth development.
recommended_dosage: Typical adult dose 100 mg every 12 hours for many infections; malaria prophylaxis and other regimens differ.
tips_for_safe_use: Avoid in pregnancy and young children (tooth staining). Use sun protection; take with water and avoid lying down immediately after taking to reduce esophageal irritation.

name: Fluconazole
description_and_medical_use: Antifungal used for many fungal infections (e.g., vaginal candidiasis, some systemic fungal infections).
common_side_effects: Nausea, headache, elevated liver enzymes (rare hepatotoxicity).
recommended_dosage: For uncomplicated vaginal thrush: single 150 mg dose orally; other infections require different dosing.
tips_for_safe_use: Check for liver disease and drug interactions (e.g., certain statins or warfarin). Use as directed by clinician.

name: Loratadine
description_and_medical_use: Second-generation oral antihistamine for allergic rhinitis and urticaria (less sedating than older antihistamines).
common_side_effects: Headache, dry mouth, rarely drowsiness.
recommended_dosage: Adults: 10 mg once daily (or as per product).
tips_for_safe_use: Generally non-sedating; avoid combining with other antihistamines unless advised. Safe for many people but check interactions.
